text: I think the biggest challenge, as Mads was saying, is really around managing overfitting properly. And that is definitely true when it comes to model selection. I've worked within several teams that over and over are making similar mistakes in the sense of like, let's say you run hundreds or thousands of experiments and each time you evaluate a certain performance metric of your model, it could be the Sharpe ratio, but it could also be non-finance related. It doesn't really matter. But I've seen certainly that when you run these many experiments, your kind of like performance metric is a random variable. And if you end up picking blindly the best model, it's the same statistically. It's the same as choosing the maximum of a random variable. And that ends up having you selecting a model that is way out in the tail from a performance metric perspective. But the expected value of that distribution is much lower. In fact, could even be negative in finance. And so you deploy a model that performs a lot less. Less well on expectation than what you've observed it in backtesting and understanding the discount factor of what you need to apply from your model selection or the performance that you see in model selection to what you should expect in completely out of sample real life. Trading is crucial. And therefore, again, coming back to, you know, how important it is to manage overfitting properly. It's been my experience that for those people who survive the quantitative journey long enough, almost everyone comes back to the fact that they're not going to be able to do it. And so I think that's a really important point to think about. It's not just about the value of everything. And I don't know whether that's we're all converging on the same thoughts because that's how you survive or whether we're all going to go extinct at the same time. But I agree. It's certainly you start to, I think the approach when you first get into quantitative finance is very naturally to try to optimize on a variable. But when you realize they're all statistically indistinguishable when you're looking at this distribution, it suddenly changes your perspective on the whole idea of model generation. There is just a lot of noise out there, right? And researchers, as they go in and become practitioners, they will realize that it's very hard to extract signal, especially in finance. Do you think there are areas which machine learning is better suited to, either areas of the markets or types of strategies that machine learning is better suited to, and areas where machine learning just may never be able to be successful? Yeah, I guess as it relates to finance, I would say one concrete example that we've seen over the last couple of years is the rise of deep learning, which has taken some areas by storm, like areas where you have high dimensional input space like computer vision or speech recognition, natural language processing, and arguably also areas where you have a lot of data and a reasonably strong signal to noise ratio. So for those areas, deep learning has... Deep learning has just blown all records out of the water completely. Are these techniques suitable for finance? Maybe, yes, no, occasionally, but they are much harder to get working for finance, partly again, because of that issue of having a very low signal to noise ratio, and in many cases, not having a lot of independent sample points. These techniques, if applied responsibly, can be useful for finance too. Ultimately, I believe that because machine learning is more like... We view machine learning as an extension. We view machine learning as a tool to our brain. We use it as a tool to essentially help us proof or disproof our hypothesis using statistical methods based on data. And I would argue that there shouldn't be any area where data is involved and hypothesis or decision making is involved that isn't considering using machine learning. Because ultimately, if you choose the appropriate techniques, they can always be supportive and helpful in trying to help you either proof or disproof your ideas or optimize them by optimizing the data. And the parameters that you give to the model that support your hypothesis.
